children.title: abomination
children.comment: That which is utterly detestable in the sight of God, particularly sin and idolatry. Daniel predicts the establishment of an ``abomination that causes desolation'' on the temple mount and Jesus Christ reiterates this prophecy.

cschildren.title: Sin is an abomination

children.title: The abomination of Babylon the Great

cschildren.title: Idolatry is an abomination
Unclean animals are an abomination
The abomination that causes desolation

children.title: addiction
children.comment: The devotion of a person to something, whether sin in general or food, alcohol or wealth in particular, so as to become dependent upon it. A person will never be satisfied in such a state of slavery. The answer to addiction is self-control through the resources of the new life in Christ.

cschildren.title: Addiction is the consequence of sin
Addiction to food, alcohol or drugs is to become dependent upon them
Addiction to wealth is to be controlled by it
Addiction never satisfies

children.title: Addiction to sinful habits does not satisfy
Addiction to food, alcohol or drugs does not satisfy
Addiction to wealth does not satisfy

cschildren.title: The answer to addiction: self-control through the new life in Christ

children.title: alienation
children.comment: A state of being separate or apart from something or someone, often accompanied by an awareness of the separation. Human beings are alienated from God on account of sin. Alienation is also encountered in other areas of life, including relations between believers, and between believers and secular society.

cschildren.title: Alienation from God because of sin

primaryrefs.comment: Those seeking to justify themselves cut themselves off from Jesus Christ's saving work

children.title: Seen in discomfort in God's presence
Seen in lost closeness with God

cschildren.title: A sense of alienation from God

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ's alienation from God as he bore the consequences of human sin was felt and actual.

cschildren.title: Alienation from others

children.title: Alienation caused by a third party

seealsos.comment: False teachers in Galatia tried to drive a wedge between Paul and the church.

secondaryrefs.comment: Job and his family and friends

cschildren.title: Overcoming alienation
God's people are aliens in the world
Responsibility to the alien

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ welcomed those who had been alienated by the rest of society.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ touched the ``untouchable'' man with leprosy

primaryrefs.comment: The weaker members of Israelite society are of special concern.
God makes special provision for the poor so that they will have a share in the blessings of the land.

seealsos.comment: The third year's tithe is shared with those without inheritance in the land.

children.title: banishment
children.comment: A form of punishment in which the guilty party is expelled from a region and forbidden to return. An important example is the banishment of Adam and Eve from Eden as a result of their disobedience to God.

cschildren.title: Banishment is a punishment for disobedience
Banishment by God

children.title: Adam and Eve were banished from Eden because of their disobedience
God banished kings as a punishment
children.precomment: Nebuchadnezzar was banished from every human being because of his sin:

secondaryrefs.comment: The king of Tyre was banished from God's presence because of his sin.

children.title: God punished the people of Judah by banishing them from their land

primaryrefs.comment: God also promised their return (Jer 32:37).

children.title: At the final judgment, God will banish all evildoers

cschildren.title: Kings used banishment as a punishment
cschildren.precomment: Saul expelled all mediums and spiritists from the land:

secondaryrefs.comment: Asa banished all the shrine-prostitutes from the land.

cschildren.title: The psalmists recognised banishment as the severest of punishments

secondaryrefs.comment: This portion of the book of Jonah is written in the same manner as the Psalms, i.e., as Hebrew poetry.

cschildren.title: The church is to use banishment as a means of discipline

children.title: blame
children.comment: The state of having been accused, correctly or incorrectly, of doing something wrong. Guilt is felt as a result of having been justly blamed for a crime or wrong against a person. Scripture portrays blaming others as a natural human reaction to events. Blame may often be apportioned by people on the basis of a misunderstanding, whereas God's blame of people is just. Christians should seek to lead blameless lives.

cschildren.title: Blaming others: a basic human characteristic since the fall
Blaming God
God justly blames his people for their sins
Warnings about falsely attributing blame
Dealing with blame
God's people should deal gently with those who deserve blame
God's people should aim to live free from blame

children.title: blemish
children.comment: A mark or stain which spoils something or lessens its value. The term is often used symbolically to refer to sin. The OT sacrificial system specified that only unblemished animals should be sacrificed.

cschildren.title: A blemish is ritually unacceptable
A blemish or stain as a symbol of sin
Without blemish: physical or moral perfection

children.title: boasting
children.comment: Negatively, conceitedly praising oneself. Positively, trusting and exulting in who God is, and what he has done.

cschildren.title: Boasting condemned
Boasting exposed as folly
Salvation by faith means no-one can boast about human merit
Examples of foolish boasting

seealsos.comment: Nebuchadnezzar
Simon the sorcerer
the antichrist

cschildren.title: Legitimate boasting

children.title: Boasting in the results of ministry
Boasting in the conduct of ministry
condemnation
children.comment: An act of judgment, in which someone rebukes and denounces the actions and motivations of others. Scripture stresses the righteousness and trustworthiness of divine condemnation but notes how human judgments are often tainted and distorted by sin.

children.title: condemnation, divine
children.comment: God's righteous condemnation is directed against human sin and wickedness.

children.title: The reality and certainty of divine condemnation
People's awareness of being under divine condemnation
Condemnation of groups, cities and nations
Divine condemnation averted through the work of Jesus Christ
condemnation, human
children.comment: The passing of judgment on others. This is valid when authorised by God, but otherwise it is frequently partial, godless and self-protecting, and therefore unacceptable.

children.title: Condemnation and the legal process: impartial judgment demanded
The perversity and injustice of human condemnation
People's false condemnation of Jesus Christ
NT warnings against judgment and condemnation
God's protection of his people from false condemnation
condemnation, divine
children.comment: God's righteous condemnation is directed against human sin and wickedness.

children.title: The reality and certainty of divine condemnation
People's awareness of being under divine condemnation
Condemnation of groups, cities and nations
Divine condemnation averted through the work of Jesus Christ
condemnation, human
children.comment: The passing of judgment on others. This is valid when authorised by God, but otherwise it is frequently partial, godless and self-protecting, and therefore unacceptable.

children.title: Condemnation and the legal process: impartial judgment demanded
The perversity and injustice of human condemnation
People's false condemnation of Jesus Christ
NT warnings against judgment and condemnation
God's protection of his people from false condemnation
corruption
children.comment: A state of spiritual decay and moral dishonesty, arising from the effects of sin, which expresses itself in disobedience towards God.

cschildren.title: Corruption of nature as a result of the fall
Sinful humanity is corrupt
The gospel breaks the power of corruption
Examples and causes of corruption

children.title: coveting
children.comment: Desiring to possess something at the expense of the legitimate owner.

children.title: coveting, prohibition of
children.comment: Coveting is forbidden by God and can lead to terrible consequences. It occasionally refers to a commendable earnest desiring.

primaryrefs.comment: Coveting is provoked by the law that forbids it.

seealsos.comment: Achan
Eli's sons
Samuel's sons
Saul
Israel's enemies are likened to the grave, always swallowing people and never satisfied
Simon the sorcerer

children.title: Believers may pray to be free from coveting
Godly people claim not to have coveted
Coveting as a commendable earnest desiring
children.precomment: A desire for the greater spiritual gifts:

secondaryrefs.comment: a desire to serve in a leadership role in the church

children.title: coveting, and other sins
children.comment: Covetousness is associated with other sins and brings trouble with it.

children.title: Coveting is linked with other sins
Covetousness is one of many sins which pollute a person
It is a source of evil
Examples of those who love money

seealsos.comment: False teachers are ``experts in greed''.

children.title: Believers must not be lovers of money

primaryrefs.comment: Elders must not be greedy for money.

children.title: Love of money characterises the last days
Even a gift can be given covetously

secondaryrefs.comment: The gift translated as ``one grudgingly given'' literally means a ``covetous gift''.

children.title: coveting, prohibition of
children.comment: Coveting is forbidden by God and can lead to terrible consequences. It occasionally refers to a commendable earnest desiring.

primaryrefs.comment: Coveting is provoked by the law that forbids it.

seealsos.comment: Achan
Eli's sons
Samuel's sons
Saul

children.title: Believers may pray to be free from coveting
Godly people claim not to have coveted
Coveting as a commendable earnest desiring

secondaryrefs.comment: a desire to serve in a leadership role in the church

children.title: coveting, and other sins
children.comment: Covetousness is associated with other sins and brings trouble with it.

children.title: Coveting is linked with other sins
Covetousness is one of many sins which pollute a person
It is a source of evil
Examples of those who love money

seealsos.comment: False teachers are ``experts in greed''.

children.title: Believers must not be lovers of money

primaryrefs.comment: Elders must not be greedy for money.

children.title: Love of money characterises the last days
Even a gift can be given covetously

secondaryrefs.comment: The gift translated as ``one grudgingly given'' literally means a ``covetous gift''.

children.title: deadness, spiritual
children.comment: Being morally and spiritually without life, therefore without a relationship with God. This condition, being the result of original sin, brings wrath and judgment and can be changed only by the sovereign, intervening grace of God.

cschildren.title: Spiritual deadness is humanity's condition by nature

children.title: It is linked to physical death
It is the universal consequence of sin
It is confirmed in the law
It is evidenced in the human mind
It is evidenced in the human body

cschildren.title: Spiritual darkness brings judgment
Rescue from spiritual deadness is initiated by God

children.title: He brings union with the death of Jesus Christ
He brings union with the resurrection of Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: Concern for those who are spiritually sleepy

children.title: decay
children.comment: As a consequence of the fall, all created things have a tendency to waste away and spoil. Jesus Christ brings deliverance from this.

cschildren.title: Decay was decreed as a result of the fall
Decay is the common experience of humanity
A decaying world is not worth clinging to
Jesus Christ is free from decay
Believers are redeemed from decay
Christians are ``salt'' in a decaying world
The world to come is free from decay
Examples of the link between sin and decay

children.title: deceit
children.comment: Behaviour, in words or actions, which is deliberately intended to make people believe things that are not true.

children.title: deceit, and God's nature
children.comment: Deceit is totally contrary to the nature and purposes of God. The gospel is grounded in the complete truthfulness and trustworthiness of God, whereas sin is based upon self-deception.

children.title: God's nature and purposes are not based on deception
Deceit is contrary to the nature of God
The coming antichrist will rely on deception
False prophets and false teachers rely on deception
Deception is at the heart of human sin
The fall took place through deception
Deception is a characteristic of fallen human nature

seealsos.comment: deceptive friends and brothers

children.title: deceit, practice of
children.comment: Deceit is condemned by God as an attempt to deny his sovereignty and his revelation of himself.

children.title: Deception must not be found in the people of God
God's people must not practise deceit
Christian leaders in particular must not deceive
God's people warned against being deceived
deceit, and God's nature
children.comment: Deceit is totally contrary to the nature and purposes of God. The gospel is grounded in the complete truthfulness and trustworthiness of God, whereas sin is based upon self-deception.

children.title: God's nature and purposes are not based on deception
Deceit is contrary to the nature of God
The coming antichrist will rely on deception
False prophets and false teachers rely on deception
Deception is at the heart of human sin
The fall took place through deception
Deception is a characteristic of fallen human nature

seealsos.comment: deceptive friends and brothers

children.title: deceit, practice of
children.comment: Deceit is condemned by God as an attempt to deny his sovereignty and his revelation of himself.

children.title: Deception must not be found in the people of God
God's people must not practise deceit
Christian leaders in particular must not deceive
God's people warned against being deceived

cschildren.title: Throwing dirt to signify contempt
Bathing to remove dirt
Comparative use of dirt to emphasise abundance
Metaphorical use of filth to represent sin
Refuse indicating worthlessness

children.title: fall, the
children.comment: The departure by creation, including human beings, from the patterns and standards set for it by God. Creation now exists at a lower level of integrity and fulfilment than that which God originally intended for it.

children.title: fall, of Adam and Eve
children.comment: The first human beings abused their God-given freedom. Their original disobedience and resultant expulsion from the Garden of Eden is usually referred to as ``the fall''.

children.title: The first sin was the disobedience of Adam and Eve to God's command
Adam and Eve tried to hide their disobedience
The disobedience of Adam and Eve affected every relationship in life
The relationship between human beings and the creation
The consequences of the disobedience of Adam and Eve
It leads to death and punishment
Sin springs from within the human mind, will and emotions
fall, of humanity
children.comment: On account of their relation to Adam, all human beings have an inherent bias towards evil due to sin. Individual acts of sin reflect this bias, often referred to as ``original sin''.

children.title: All human beings, except for Jesus Christ, are sinful
Every part of a person is affected by sin
Believers are warned not to fall from grace
God is able to keep believers from falling
fall, of Satan and his angels
children.comment: Satan and his angels rebelled against God and were removed from their positions of authority. They are now destined for judgment.

children.title: The rebellion of Satan and his angels

primaryrefs.comment: Written about a king in Isaiah's own time, this passage has been used by both Jews and Christians as a description of the fall of Satan

children.title: The results of the rebellion of Satan and his angels
Constant spiritual warfare on the earth
fall, of Adam and Eve
children.comment: The first human beings abused their God-given freedom. Their original disobedience and resultant expulsion from the Garden of Eden is usually referred to as ``the fall''.

children.title: The first sin was the disobedience of Adam and Eve to God's command
Adam and Eve tried to hide their disobedience
The disobedience of Adam and Eve affected every relationship in life
The relationship between human beings and the creation
The consequences of the disobedience of Adam and Eve
It leads to death and punishment
Sin springs from within the human mind, will and emotions
fall, of humanity
children.comment: On account of their relation to Adam, all human beings have an inherent bias towards evil due to sin. Individual acts of sin reflect this bias, often referred to as ``original sin''.

children.title: All human beings, except for Jesus Christ, are sinful
Every part of a person is affected by sin
Believers are warned not to fall from grace
God is able to keep believers from falling
fall, of Satan and his angels
children.comment: Satan and his angels rebelled against God and were removed from their positions of authority. They are now destined for judgment.

children.title: The rebellion of Satan and his angels

primaryrefs.comment: Written about a king in Isaiah's own time, this passage has been used by both Jews and Christians as a description of the fall of Satan

children.title: The results of the rebellion of Satan and his angels
Constant spiritual warfare on the earth
fathers, sin of the
children.comment: Children may suffer on account of the sins committed by their forebears, just as they may also be blessed for their sake. Nevertheless, Scripture teaches that each individual must take responsibility for his or her own sin.

cschildren.title: Children suffer the ill-effects of their fathers' sins
The exilic prophets emphasised individual responsibility for sin
Children share in the blessing of their fathers

children.title: faults
children.comment: Human weaknesses and failings which are sinful in themselves, and may lead to further sin. It is common, often as a means of averting blame, to put undue focus on the faults of others. However, where necessary, faults should be exposed and responsibility properly attributed. Jesus Christ lived a faultless life and God's people are challenged to live lives that are above reproach. The church will one day be presented without fault before God.

cschildren.title: The variety of human faults

children.title: Faults in thought, word and deed

secondaryrefs.comment: selfishness in going one's own way
failure to do what is right

cschildren.title: Finding fault with others

primaryrefs.comment: Adam blames Eve for his disobedience.

seealsos.comment: Aaron blames the Israelites for the golden calf
Saul blames his troops' impatience and Samuel's late arrival for his disobedience
Saul blames his soldiers for the failure to carry out God's instructions
The man who buried his talent blames his action on his master's hardness.

children.title: Finding fault with God's appointed leaders

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ is accused of blasphemy because he claims to forgive sin
Jesus Christ is criticised for his association with ``sinners''
Jesus Christ is criticised for failure to conform to ceremonial cleansing traditions
false charges brought against Jesus Christ at his trial
Jesus Christ is accused of breaking the Sabbath.

cschildren.title: Confronting human faults

children.title: Accepting blame for one's own faults
God holds his people at fault
Faults cannot be hidden from God
Examples of those confronted with their faults

cschildren.title: God can deal with human faults

children.title: Freedom from the power of sin

cschildren.title: Faultlessness

children.title: God's people are to be above reproach

seealsos.comment: Paul ensures that his handling of money is above criticism

children.title: The church will be presented faultless before God
flesh, sinful nature
children.comment: The physical aspect of human beings, which distinguishes them from God and is therefore frequently used in the NT as a symbol of human sinful nature in contrast with God's perfection. (The Greek word for ``flesh'' is sometimes translated by other words and phrases in the passages cited in this theme.).

cschildren.title: Flesh as the bodily substance of human beings

children.title: As individuals or in relation to others
As the means by which Jesus Christ identified with the human race to bring salvation

cschildren.title: Flesh as contrasting human nature with God's perfection

children.title: The powerlessness of human beings contrasted with God's eternal power
Human or worldly standards contrasted with God's standards

cschildren.title: Flesh as denoting the sinful nature of human beings

primaryrefs.comment: Paul does not mean that no goodness at all exists in people; nor that the physical aspect of human beings is inherently evil. He means that humans are invariably infected by evil and subject to its power.

children.title: The conflict in human experience between the sinful nature and the Spirit of God

cschildren.title: The sinful nature is opposed to God and his will

children.title: This opposition finds expression in a range of acts and attitudes
Confidence in the law is futile

primaryrefs.comment: Because of the sinfulness of human nature, God's law is powerless to bring people into relationship with God
Even the attempt to find acceptance with God through keeping his law is an act of the sinful nature because it involves rejecting his offer of salvation through his grace.

children.title: The sinful nature controls human behaviour in ways which run counter to God's purpose

cschildren.title: The sinful nature therefore makes people subject to God's judgment and to death
Believers are not controlled by the sinful nature

children.title: Through Jesus Christ's entering into human flesh, God delivers from the power and consequences of human sinfulness
Believers have crucified the sinful nature
The power of God's Spirit enables believers to continue to resist the sinful nature
God's provision of church discipline in eliminating the sinful nature

primaryrefs.comment: The discipline of excluding a sinner from the church community is intended to bring him to repentance and so abandon his sinful course of action. Repentance provoked by physical suffering is possibly also in mind.

children.title: godlessness
children.comment: An outlook and lifestyle which does not acknowledge God. God frustrates the evil purposes of the godless and judges them. Believers are to guard against godlessness.

cschildren.title: Godlessness is an outlook and lifestyle which does not acknowledge God
Examples of godlessness
God frustrates the evil purposes of the godless
God judges godless people and nations
Believers are to guard against godlessness
Jesus Christ will turn godlessness away from Israel

children.title: guilt
children.comment: Primarily a state of being at fault, often accompanied by a feeling of being in the wrong. Scripture affirms that human guilt arises from sin before God, and can only be purged through accepting the forgiveness offered through the death of Jesus Christ.

children.title: guilt, and God
children.comment: All human beings are guilty in the sight of God, and all require forgiveness and expiation of their sin. Guilt can arise through failing to know what is right, through failing to do what is right and through giving in to temptation to do wrong.

children.title: Guilt as the objective condition of sinners
Guilt as an accumulation of sin
God's determination to punish the guilty
Human judges are to punish the guilty
guilt, human aspects of
children.comment: Scripture affirms that all are guilty in the sight of God, and explores the various ways in which guilt affects human life, before offering forgiveness of guilt through the death of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Human beings are held responsible for their guilt
Guilt produces feelings of anguish and despair
Guilt produces feelings of shame and disgrace
Guilt produces feelings of fear and terror

seealsos.comment: The fear of being cast out of God's presence is the result of the psalmist's sense of guilt

children.title: guilt, removal of
children.comment: Through the death of Jesus Christ, God has provided a means of removing guilt, thus opening the way for believers to know the blessings of a right relationship with him.

children.title: The removal of guilt is God's work

primaryrefs.comment: ``Justify'' is a legal term which includes the meaning ``to declare not guilty''.

children.title: The removal of guilt requires confession
The removal of guilt by the OT sacrificial system
Guilt removed by the guilt offering
Guilt removed by the sin offering
Guilt removed by the Day of Atonement
Animal sacrifices are ultimately ineffective in removing guilt
The removal of guilt by Jesus Christ's sacrificial death

primaryrefs.comment: This prophecy finds its ultimate fulfilment in the person of Jesus Christ

seealsos.comment: The point of John's image is that Jesus Christ will be sacrificed, as lambs were, to remove people's guilt
The blood of Jesus Christ referred to here is his shed blood, and therefore speaks of his (sacrificial) death
Human guilt is transferred to Jesus Christ, in order that believers might become righteous before God

children.title: The results of guilt being removed

hardness of heart
children.comment: Primarily, in Scripture, a persistent inner refusal to hear and obey the word of God. Also, in a more general sense, an uncaring or unsympathetic attitude towards other people.

cschildren.title: Kinds of hardness of heart

primaryrefs.comment: Referring to the disobedience of the Israelites in their wilderness wanderings.
God's judgment on Pharaoh was to confirm him in his stubbornness so that he might feel the full weight of his wrath

children.title: As an uncaring attitude towards other people

cschildren.title: Examples of hardness of heart
God's remedies for hardness of heart

primaryrefs.comment: God's promise to Israel.

children.title: ignorance
children.comment: A state of lack of knowledge or information, including a failure to know the person, will and ways of God. Scripture emphasises the importance of a true knowledge of God and makes such knowledge available.

children.title: ignorance, and human situation
children.comment: Ignorance is part of the human condition: as finite creatures, human knowledge is incomplete, but human beings can trust God, whose knowledge is complete, to guide their steps.

children.title: Finite human beings cannot know God completely
This ignorance will be dispelled at Jesus Christ's return
Human beings are ignorant of future events
Human beings are ignorant of the time of Jesus Christ's return
Presumptious plans should therefore be avoided
God has established teachers to combat ignorance
ignorance, of God
children.comment: A lack of knowledge of God, regarded as inexcusable by Scripture. God has made his existence, nature and power known to all through creation. God himself is not ignorant of human sin, but is able to discern the real intentions of human minds and wills.

children.title: God is made known through creation

primaryrefs.comment: As God is made known to all through nature, human ignorance of God is inexcusable.

children.title: Ignorance of God is linked to sin and rebellion
Ignorance of God in the ministry of Jesus Christ
God is not ignorant of human sin and motives
Human ignorance of sin and the revelation of God
The fall brought knowledge of sin
The OT law exposed the nature of sin
Human ignorance does not excuse sin

primaryrefs.comment: The law made provision for atonement of sins committed as a result of ignorance.

children.title: Sin committed in ignorance incurs a lesser judgment than other sin
Repentance of sin committed in ignorance brings forgiveness
There is no salvation outside Jesus Christ
Believers have a responsibility to remove ignorance of the gospel
The justice of God in salvation
God's judgment falls on all who do not know him
God's judgment falls severely on those who choose to disobey him
ignorance, and human situation
children.comment: Ignorance is part of the human condition: as finite creatures, human knowledge is incomplete, but human beings can trust God, whose knowledge is complete, to guide their steps.

children.title: Finite human beings cannot know God completely
This ignorance will be dispelled at Jesus Christ's return
Human beings are ignorant of future events
Human beings are ignorant of the time of Jesus Christ's return

children.comment: A lack of knowledge of God, regarded as inexcusable by Scripture. God has made his existence, nature and power known to all through creation. God himself is not ignorant of human sin, but is able to discern the real intentions of human minds and wills.

imagination
children.comment: The human ability to form mental pictures, often used to refer to human desires or schemes which are inclined towards evil. Scripture often treats the human heart as the focus of the imagination.

children.title: imagination, inward desires
children.comment: The usually sinful inclinations of a heart which is by nature corrupt and stubborn, but which may be renewed by God, resulting in purified desires.

children.title: The heart is the source of human desires

seealsos.comment: God's choice of David
The plot of Jeremiah's enemies is revealed to him by the LORD
Jesus Christ knows the thoughts of others.

children.title: Corruption finds particular expression in sexual sin
It leads to disregard for God
God allows people to continue in their stubbornness
God delights in a pure heart
God fulfils the desires of hearts devoted to him
God gives the desire to follow him
The human ability to visualise in parables
imagination, evil scheming
children.comment: Human thinking, darkened by sin, expressed in plans which are in opposition to God and which seek to take advantage of others.

children.title: Human thought is darkened by sin
As a result of rejecting God's revelation
As a result of excessive alcohol
As a result of Satan's activity
Sinful human thinking finds expression in evil ways

seealsos.comment: warnings against evil thinking as the year for cancelling debts approaches
Jewish religious leaders plot against Jesus Christ.

children.title: Human plans are an expression of pride
False prophecy comes from evil thinking
imagination, inward desires
children.comment: The usually sinful inclinations of a heart which is by nature corrupt and stubborn, but which may be renewed by God, resulting in purified desires.

children.title: The heart is the source of human desires

God allows people to continue in their stubbornness
God delights in a pure heart
God fulfils the desires of hearts devoted to him
God gives the desire to follow him
The human ability to visualise in parables
imagination, evil scheming
children.comment: Human thinking, darkened by sin, expressed in plans which are in opposition to God and which seek to take advantage of others.

children.title: Human thought is darkened by sin
As a result of rejecting God's revelation
As a result of excessive alcohol
As a result of Satan's activity
Sinful human thinking finds expression in evil ways

seealsos.comment: warnings against evil thinking as the year for cancelling debts approaches
Jewish religious leaders plot against Jesus Christ.

children.title: Human plans are an expression of pride
False prophecy comes from evil thinking
immorality
children.comment: Behaviour which is contrary to the will of God for his people. Although the term may be used to refer to a wide range of immoral actions, it is used especially in relation to unacceptable sexual behaviour.

children.title: immorality, nature of sexual
children.comment: Sexual behaviour which is contrary to God's law.

children.title: Sexual immorality is widespread in the world
Sexual immorality has no place in the Christian life

seealsos.comment: Lot's daughters
more likely referring to his stepmother

children.title: Sexual immorality as a picture of spiritual unfaithfulness

seealsos.comment: reflecting the immorality of the pagan religions in which Israel had indulged

children.title: immorality, nature of sexual
children.comment: Sexual behaviour which is contrary to God's law.

children.title: Sexual immorality is widespread in the world
Sexual immorality has no place in the Christian life

seealsos.comment: Lot's daughters
more likely referring to his stepmother

children.title: Sexual immorality as a picture of spiritual unfaithfulness

seealsos.comment: reflecting the immorality of the pagan religions in which Israel had indulged

children.title: impenitence
children.comment: A deliberate and persistent refusal to repent or to submit to God's will.

children.title: impenitence, warnings against
children.comment: Scripture stresses the seriousness of impenitence. Despite the goodness of God, some sinners refuse to repent and turn to him in faith.

children.title: Impenitence is a refusal to turn from sin
Impenitence in spite of God's invitations and and warnings
Impenitence in spite of God's dealings
Impenitence in spite of God's punishment
Impenitence in spite of God's goodness

seealsos.comment: Although inappropriate for Job, the advice is still valid

children.title: There is no remedy for persistent impenitence
impenitence, results of
children.comment: The seriousness of the failure to repent is frequently underlined in Scripture, which provides numerous examples of impenitence and its consequences.

children.title: Storing up wrath for the day of judgment
impenitence, warnings against
children.comment: Scripture stresses the seriousness of impenitence. Despite the goodness of God, some sinners refuse to repent and turn to him in faith.

children.title: Impenitence is a refusal to turn from sin
Impenitence in spite of God's invitations and and warnings
Impenitence in spite of God's dealings
Impenitence in spite of God's punishment
Impenitence in spite of God's goodness

seealsos.comment: Although inappropriate for Job, the advice is still valid

children.title: There is no remedy for persistent impenitence
impenitence, results of
children.comment: The seriousness of the failure to repent is frequently underlined in Scripture, which provides numerous examples of impenitence and its consequences.

children.title: Storing up wrath for the day of judgment
imperfection
children.comment: The state of incompletion or decay that characterises the fallen world. Although God created the world perfect, it lapsed into its present state of imperfection through human sin.

children.title: imperfection, influence of
children.comment: Scripture indicates that the world, including human beings and institutions, are imperfect because of the contaminating influence of sin. This influence extends to the household of faith: both Israel and the Christian church are portrayed as prone to sin and weakness.

children.title: The creation is imperfect because of sin
Imperfection is expressed in corruption and death
The imperfection of the spiritual creation
The universal imperfection of human beings
The imperfection of the household of faith
The Christian church and its leaders
imperfection, and God's purposes
children.comment: The unacceptable falling short of the God-given ideal must be resisted and overcome.

children.title: Imperfection is contrary to God's purpose
Imperfection is unacceptable in God's presence
The priests must be physically perfect
God's people should strive against imperfection
Imperfection will be dealt with at Jesus Christ's return
imperfection, influence of
children.comment: Scripture indicates that the world, including human beings and institutions, are imperfect because of the contaminating influence of sin. This influence extends to the household of faith: both Israel and the Christian church are portrayed as prone to sin and weakness.

children.title: The creation is imperfect because of sin
Imperfection is expressed in corruption and death
The imperfection of the spiritual creation
The universal imperfection of human beings
The imperfection of the household of faith
The Christian church and its leaders
imperfection, and God's purposes
children.comment: The unacceptable falling short of the God-given ideal must be resisted and overcome.

children.title: Imperfection is contrary to God's purpose
Imperfection is unacceptable in God's presence
The priests must be physically perfect
God's people should strive against imperfection
Imperfection will be dealt with at Jesus Christ's return
mortality
children.comment: The human state of being subject to death and decay. God did not create human beings to be like this; mortality is the consequence of sin and is countered by the gospel promise of eternal life in Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: Mortality originated in the fall

children.title: It is the decree of God
It is a judgment from God

cschildren.title: Mortality extends to the creation

children.title: Human beings likened to the animals
Human beings likened to the grass

cschildren.title: The natural reaction to mortality
The godly reaction to mortality
Death is not the end

children.title: offence
children.comment: A transgression or affront against the law or an individual. The gospel itself is seen as offensive by unbelievers, who are often unable to cope with its radical challenge to their unbelief.

cschildren.title: Legal offence
Moral offence
An offence to others

seealsos.comment: Abigail seeks David's forgiveness for Nabal's offence
The people of Nazareth take offence at Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: Offence against God

primaryrefs.comment: Offence against God is synonymous with sin.

seealsos.comment: ``wrongs'', ``sins'' and ``offence'' are three important OT terms for sin
Ezekiel warns that the soul who sins will die

cschildren.title: Offence against God's house
The things of God are an offence to sinful people
A stumbling-block as an object of offence

primaryrefs.comment: The concept behind the English word ``offence'' is one of striking against something or someone. The image of a stumbling-block conveys the idea of tripping or falling as a result of striking against such an object.

children.title: A stumbling-block set up by God

cschildren.title: OT use of the term ``pagan''

children.title: Used of foreign adherents of heathen religions
Used of heathen religions, peoples and countries

cschildren.title: In the Gospels ``pagans'' is synonymous with ``Gentiles''
The term ``pagans'' is used to refer to people who were neither Jews nor Christians

children.title: Many believers lived among the pagans
participation
children.comment: Sharing in actions or identifying with actions or people. All human beings share in Adam's fall and its consequences; believers share in Christ and his life.

children.title: participation, in sin
children.comment: The natural condition of all human beings as a result of sharing in Adam's fall. Believers are called not to associate with, nor give approval to wickedness but to stand apart from evil as God's holy people.

seealsos.comment: giving hospitality to evildoers

children.title: God's people are not to participate in evil
God's people are called to be holy

primaryrefs.comment: Too close an association with the nations round about, particularly in marriage, would cause Israel to compromise her unique relationship with God
Often related to marriage, this applies to all close alliances with unbelievers.

children.title: participation, in Christ
children.comment: The joining of believers to Jesus Christ, through faith, whereby they are freed from participation in Adam by sharing in Christ's death and resurrection, his nature, sufferings and glory and whereby, too, they become part of his body. Believers therefore share in the fellowship, ministry and hope of God's people, which is anticipated by the OT and fulfilled in the church.

children.title: Faith liberates from participation in sin

primaryrefs.comment: Paul thanks the Philippians for their active support of his ministry.

children.title: Participation of the nations in God's salvation
Gentiles are included among God's people
God's promise to include the nations
participation, in sin
children.comment: The natural condition of all human beings as a result of sharing in Adam's fall. Believers are called not to associate with, nor give approval to wickedness but to stand apart from evil as God's holy people.

seealsos.comment: giving hospitality to evildoers

children.title: God's people are not to participate in evil
God's people are called to be holy

primaryrefs.comment: Too close an association with the nations round about, particularly in marriage, would cause Israel to compromise her unique relationship with God
Often related to marriage, this applies to all close alliances with unbelievers.

Believers therefore share in the fellowship, ministry and hope of God's people, which is anticipated by the OT and fulfilled in the church.

children.title: Faith liberates from participation in sin

primaryrefs.comment: Paul thanks the Philippians for their active support of his ministry.

children.title: Participation of the nations in God's salvation
Gentiles are included among God's people
God's promise to include the nations
provoking God
children.comment: The arousing of God's righteous anger in response to the sin of his people, particularly their idolatry.

cschildren.title: God is provoked by sin and disobedience

seealsos.comment: Uzzah's disobedience in touching the ark cost him his life

cschildren.title: God is provoked by the rejection of his chosen leaders and prophets
God is provoked by injustice
God is provoked by complaining
God is provoked by idolatry
God is provoked by human sacrifice

children.title: rebellion
children.comment: A state of revolt against established divine or human authority. Scripture condemns rebellion against God and indicates the futility of Israel's frequent rebellions against him.

children.title: rebellion, against God
children.comment: The human race is in rebellion against God through its disobedience and unbelief.

children.title: Indignation expressed over rebellion against God
God is ready to forgive those who rebel against him
The end times will be characterised by open rebellion against God
rebellion, of Israel
children.comment: Despite God's repeated mercy, Israel's history is seen as a history of rebellion against God.

children.title: The history of Israel is seen as a history of rebellion
God's compassion and readiness to deliver his people
Isaiah depicts Israel as a rebellious nation
Jeremiah denounces the Israelites as rebels
Ezekiel condemns Israel as a rebellious house
The rebellion of Israel in the parables of Jesus Christ
Israel's rebellion is a warning to believers
rebellion, against human authority
children.comment: Human authority is frequently defied and resisted. To rebel against God's chosen leaders is to defy God himself.

children.title: Examples of rebellion against human leaders
Rebellion against legitimate authority is condemned
rebellion, against God
children.comment: The human race is in rebellion against God through its disobedience and unbelief.

children.title: Indignation expressed over rebellion against God
God is ready to forgive those who rebel against him
The end times will be characterised by open rebellion against God
rebellion, of Israel
children.comment: Despite God's repeated mercy, Israel's history is seen as a history of rebellion against God.

children.title: The history of Israel is seen as a history of rebellion
God's compassion and readiness to deliver his people
Isaiah depicts Israel as a rebellious nation
Jeremiah denounces the Israelites as rebels
Ezekiel condemns Israel as a rebellious house
The rebellion of Israel in the parables of Jesus Christ
Israel's rebellion is a warning to believers
rebellion, against human authority
children.comment: Human authority is frequently defied and resisted. To rebel against God's chosen leaders is to defy God himself.

children.title: Examples of rebellion against human leaders
Rebellion against legitimate authority is condemned
regret
children.comment: Deep feelings of sorrow arising from past events now seen as sins, mistakes or misfortunes. It can either lead to true repentance or destructive bitterness.

cschildren.title: Examples and expressions of regret

seealsos.comment: Aaron and Miriam when they had spoken against Moses
Jephthah when he returned home from fighting the Ammonites
Ahab after he murdered Naboth and seized his vineyard
Peter when he disowned Jesus Christ
Judas after betraying Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: Divine expressions of regret
Actions which may lead to regret
The bitterness of vain regrets

children.title: There is no remedy for bitter regrets
The unending remorse of the lost

cschildren.title: Regret is an element of true repentance

seealsos.comment: Josiah's response on finding the Book of the Law
the repentance of Nineveh
the prodigal son

cschildren.title: Absence of regret

children.title: rejection
children.comment: The deliberate and conscious act of turning away from someone, or refusing to accept something that is being offered.

children.title: rejection of God
children.comment: The deliberate rejection of God lies at the heart of human sin. It is seen in rebellion against God's authority, purpose and instruction and results in the rejection of God's servants and, ultimately, in the rejection of his Son.

children.title: Rejection of God in favour of other gods

primaryrefs.comment: It is generally accepted that God's servant in Isaiah chapter 53 refers to Jesus Christ

children.title: The rejection of his earthly ministry
rejection of God, results of
children.comment: Rejecting God angers and grieves him. To reject God can be to reject all the benefits of the gospel, and can lead to judgment and punishment.

children.title: God rejected by Israel, his vineyard
Rejection angers God and brings his wrath
God rejects those who reject him
God rejects the sanctuary and its worship
God's people are removed from his presence into exile
Examples of others rejected by God
rejection, human experience of
children.comment: Feelings of rejection by God may be a result of alienation caused directly or indirectly by sin. God's people also experience rejection by a hostile world. Experiences and feelings of rejection are to be met with prayer, forgiveness and perseverance, together with confidence in God's commitment to and compassion for, his people.

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ experiences separation from his Father as a consequence of bearing human sin.

seealsos.comment: God's readiness to forgive is to be reflected in the attitude of his people towards one another.

children.title: rejection of God
children.comment: The deliberate rejection of God lies at the heart of human sin. It is seen in rebellion against God's authority, purpose and instruction and results in the rejection of God's servants and, ultimately, in the rejection of his Son.

children.title: Rejection of God in favour of other gods

primaryrefs.comment: It is generally accepted that God's servant in Isaiah chapter 53 refers to Jesus Christ

children.title: The rejection of his earthly ministry

Rejection angers God and brings his wrath

Experiences and feelings of rejection are to be met with prayer, forgiveness and perseverance, together with confidence in God's commitment to and compassion for, his people.

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ experiences separation from his Father as a consequence of bearing human sin.

seealsos.comment: God's readiness to forgive is to be reflected in the attitude of his people towards one another.

children.title: sexual sin
children.comment: Sexual relations are to be seen as an aspect of God's good creation which can be corrupted and devalued through human sin.

children.title: sexual sin, nature of
children.comment: Any transgression of the limits that God has set for the enjoyment of sex. Such sins are often life-dominating, but may be broken through the power and grace of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Sexual sin under the old covenant
Sexual sin under the new covenant
The OT laws are confirmed and strengthened
The need for holiness in the lives of believers
The church must be kept pure
By enjoying sex within proper limits
homosexuality
children.comment: Sexual relations between people of the same sex. The biblical emphasis upon the loving union of male and female, as an integral part of God's creation ordinance, establishes the context against which the censure of homosexual practice is to be set.

children.title: Homosexual practice is incompatible with the kingdom of God

primaryrefs.comment: The meanings of the Greek words for ``male prostitutes'' and ``homosexual offenders'' are disputed, but the terms are commonly associated with particular forms of homosexual behaviour.

children.title: Sexual disorder is one consequence of rejecting God

secondaryrefs.comment: in Israel in a time of moral decadence

children.title: prostitution
children.comment: Scripture condemns the offering of sex for money or favours. However, it also stresses the prospect of new life in Christ for prostitutes, and points to some prostitutes as examples of faith.

children.title: It was forbidden under God's law
Priests were forbidden to marry prostitutes
rape
children.comment: The sexual violation of an individual (normally, though not necessarily, female). This is a deeply traumatic and degrading experience for the victim and is an evil that Scripture condemns.

children.title: Lust is the motivation for rape
Women are particularly vulnerable to male assault
Women were protected under the law
Women are to be loved and cared for
seduction
children.comment: The deliberate enticement or persuasion of someone into the abandonment of godly principles. Scripture speaks of both sexual and spiritual seduction.

children.title: Through lying spirits and false prophets
Persistence on the part of the seducer
adultery
children.comment: Sexual relations involving at least one partner who is married to someone else. Such relations break the marriage covenant and are condemned in Scripture. Jesus Christ extended the understanding of adultery to include inner lust.

children.title: It is listed with other evil practices
It is a snare to the unwary
It is resisted by the wise
It was punishable by death under OT law
Remarriage after divorce may be adultery

seealsos.comment: the people of Jerusalem
the exiles in Babylon
Hosea's wife, Gomer
the woman caught in adultery
false teachers in the church

primaryrefs.comment: ``offspring of adulterers'' was a term of abuse.

seealsos.comment: David and Bathsheba's child died when he was seven days old

children.title: adultery, spiritual
children.comment: In Scripture there is a close link between sexual sin and spiritual corruption and immorality as promoted by false teachers. Scripture frequently uses the language of sexual sin to expose the infidelity of God's people.

children.title: The link between sexual sin and spiritual adultery
Spiritual adultery and God's covenant relationship with his people
God as a husband to his people

primaryrefs.comment: The spiritual relationship between God and his people is defined in terms of the intimate and exclusive bond of marriage.

children.title: God is jealous for his people's affections

primaryrefs.comment: Just as husband and wife are jealous for their relationship in love, so God is jealous for the affections of his people.

children.title: The history of spiritual adultery among God's people
In the northern kingdom of Israel
In the southern kingdom of Judah
Believers are not to be drawn into spiritual adultery

In the northern kingdom of Israel

stubbornness
children.comment: Proud and disobedient resistance to God's will and rejection of his commands.

cschildren.title: Stubbornness is an attitude of heart
The practical consequences of stubbornness

seealsos.comment: sudden destruction for the unrepentant
a humbling on judgment day
King Nebuchadnezzar deposed
The people of Israel forget their God
Jesus Christ's disciples amazed
The self-righteous store up wrath for the day of judgment.

cschildren.title: Commands not to be stubborn
Stubbornness can be God's judgment on sin

primaryrefs.comment: When people persistently refuse to obey God, he brings about a condition where they cannot obey him, and consequently cannot receive his blessing.

cschildren.title: God's appeal to stubborn people

children.title: temptation
children.comment: Pressure to yield to influences that can lead people away from God and into sin.

children.title: temptation, universality of
children.comment: Scripture makes clear that all human beings are subject to temptation. It provides examples of individuals who have faced and yielded to such influences.

children.title: The inevitability of temptation to do wrong
Examples of those who were tempted

primaryrefs.comment: Sin enters the world through temptation, which leads to the fall of humanity.

children.title: temptation, sources of
children.comment: Temptation comes from a number of sources but not from God.

children.title: Temptation arising from sinful human nature
Temptation does not come from God
temptation, resisting
children.comment: Being tempted is not in itself a sin. Sin arises when believers give in to temptation. Scripture urges believers to resist temptation, and gives them encouragement to face it.

children.title: Finding in God and his word resources to overcome temptation
Examples of those who did not give in to temptation
temptation, and Jesus Christ
children.comment: Jesus Christ, like every other human being, knew temptation. However, he never yielded to it. The sinlessness of Christ refers to his obedient refusal to give in to temptation. It does not mean that he did not experience temptation himself.

children.title: The temptation to avoid the cross
The temptation to please the crowd
The significance of the temptation of Jesus Christ
Believers can identify with Jesus Christ in his temptation
Believers can have confidence in the face of temptation
temptation, avoiding causing
children.comment: Any behaviour which might cause others to do wrong is to be avoided.

children.title: Special care is needed to avoid tempting those whose faith is young
Temptation is linked to passing judgment on others
Allowance must be made to avoid causing temptation to those whose faith is weak
Avoiding causing temptation by exercising Christian freedom responsibly
Examples of restraining sin or temptation

children.comment: Scripture makes clear that all human beings are subject to temptation. It provides examples of individuals who have faced and yielded to such influences.

unbelievers
children.comment: Those who are unwilling to believe and trust in God, especially as he has made himself known in and through Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: Characteristics of unbelievers

children.title: A refusal to believe in God
A refusal to trust in God

cschildren.title: Descriptions of unbelievers
Unbelievers can become believers
The effect of tongues and prophecy on unbelievers
Relationships between believers and unbelievers
The consequence of remaining an unbeliever
Examples of unbelievers

children.title: uncircumcised
children.comment: Those who are outside the covenant of God.

cschildren.title: Circumcision marked the covenant people of God

children.title: Uncircumcised aliens participating in Jewish religious practices had first to be circumcised

cschildren.title: The term ``uncircumcised''
Uncircumcision represents a wrong inner spiritual attitude

primaryrefs.comment: The tribes mentioned also practised male circumcision.

cschildren.title: In Christ the barrier between the circumcised and uncircumcised is overcome
